head.title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Fish Trade Dispute

hedline.hl1: World Business Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Fish Trade Dispute

abstract.p: Commerce Department, in preliminary finding, rules that Viethamese catfish farmers are guilty of dumping discount-priced frozen fish on market in US and could be liable for import duties as high as 63 percent; American catfish farmers have persuaded Congress to bar Vietnam from using name catfish for their exports and then filed suit that led to decision; Vietnamese condemn suit and say it is in violation of new trade agreement with US (S)

block.p: In a preliminary finding, the Bush administration ruled that Vietnamese catfish farmers are guilty of dumping discount-priced frozen fish on the market in the United States and could be liable for import duties as high as 63 percent. In what is becoming a major trade war, American catfish farmers have persuaded Congress to bar Vietnam from using the name catfish for their exports and then filed the suit that led to yesterday's decision by the Commerce Department. For their part, the Vietnamese have condemned the suit as ''an unfair, protectionist act'' and a violation of the new trade agreement with the United States. They said their fish were priced lower because Vietnamese labor costs far less than American labor. In the last three years, Vietnamese catfish exports have soared from $13 million to $55 million, capturing 20 percent of the American market. A final decision is expected in June.

In a preliminary finding, the Bush administration ruled that Vietnamese catfish farmers are guilty of dumping discount-priced frozen fish on the market in the United States and could be liable for import duties as high as 63 percent. In what is becoming a major trade war, American catfish farmers have persuaded Congress to bar Vietnam from using the name catfish for their exports and then filed the suit that led to yesterday's decision by the Commerce Department. For their part, the Vietnamese have condemned the suit as ''an unfair, protectionist act'' and a violation of the new trade agreement with the United States. They said their fish were priced lower because Vietnamese labor costs far less than American labor. In the last three years, Vietnamese catfish exports have soared from $13 million to $55 million, capturing 20 percent of the American market. A final decision is expected in June.
